data.title: "No Prospect of Recovery"
data.text:
Two23

Offline

    

: Off

p.2 #3 · p.2 #3 · "No Prospect of Recovery"

utildayael wrote:

Doubtful. Assuming they have business insurance it is just going to hurt for a short bit while they re-located and re-build..

Quite a few companies do what's called "self insure. Instead of paying regular insurance premiums, they put the money aside for emergencies. I bet it will take most of next year for Nikon to be up and running near normal. Remember, not only have they lost their equipment etc., but they have lost the profit from the sales too. A lot of camera companies went out of business after the destruction of WW2.

The cameras I was thinking of Nikon making in the mid 1950s were the S-mount rangefinders, not the F mount of 1959.

Another thought--what about parts for when our current stuff breaks? I sent a Nikon SB-800 in to LA repair facility several weeks ago and haven't heard back from them at all.

Kent in SD

Zebrabot

Offline

  

: Off

p.2 #5 · p.2 #5 · "No Prospect of Recovery"

Rodolfo Paiz wrote:

I'd have preferred not to say anything, but I can't not say anything.

Are you sure you don't want to rethink, rephrase, or reword that post, if only for the benefit of your public image?

Nope. I'm not a politician, I don't need a phoney public image.

Lots of companies moved to thailand because the labor is cheap. It also floods alot, which apparently everybody forgot about. Whoops.

It's just like the american companies that move their manufacturing to mexico. Quite a few of them found the hard way the labor is cheaper per man hour, but the productivity is incredibly low and unless you send over all your american workers you fired to go there and supervise and crack the whip nobody will do any work. Large companies can sometimes pull it off, lots of small ones fail trying this.

It's the same with outsourcing stuff to india. Yeah, payroll will be lower, but you're not going to get nearly as much work done unless you have a fairly large operation there, and not some shack with 5 people waiting around the fax machine 23 hours a day for orders from HQ in the united states to come in, if the phone lines still work.

M635_Guy

Offline

   

: Off

p.2 #8 · p.2 #8 · "No Prospect of Recovery"

...Show more →

How many of these places have you been to, or do you just read a lot?

Rodolfo Paiz

     

: On

p.2 #10 · p.2 #10 · "No Prospect of Recovery"

I can only speculate that you must have poor taste, or low standards, in the companies for whom you choose to work. I've worked in 12 countries so far and been to nearly 30 overall. I'm well-acquainted with most of Latin America -- from there, in fact -- and I've worked with a lot of companies (suppliers and/or clients) who have significant relationships with India, China, and other parts of Asia.

From everything I've seen, the stuff you're saying sounds like heavily-spun, politically-motivated sound bites pulled from propaganda and a few choice U.S. TV channels. It also sounds personally bitter, as though perhaps (again, speculation only) your bias comes from one of those outsourced jobs having been yours at some point. Phrases and terms like "cheap slum foreign country" and "some shack with 5 people waiting around the fax machine" only make your emotional bias more apparent, and your statements less credible.

penghai

Offline

  

: Off

p.2 #12 · p.2 #12 · "No Prospect of Recovery"

AxisSally wrote:

Nikon Corp.s Thailand plant produces low- to mid-range single-lens reflex cameras

Other than the flooding being a tragedy, the above could mean we will see a D800 still sometime soon

I really doubt D800 will be there any time soon. The low end DSLR is Nikon's bread and butter line. Now that line is down. Nikon's first priority must be to solve the manufacturing of these low end DSLRs. Other products may be put to lower priority.

For those who need a Christmas gift from Nikon, look at one of the Nikon 1 cameras. That may be the only new cameras this year.

Eric

Two23

Offline

    

: Off

p.2 #13 · p.2 #13 · "No Prospect of Recovery"

penghai wrote:

I really doubt D800 will be there any time soon. The low end DSLR is Nikon's bread and butter line. Now that line is down. Nikon's first priority must be to solve the manufacturing of these low end DSLRs. Other products may be put to lower priority.

I agree, and will add that if D800 is/was to be made in Sendai, don't forget that area is crippled by a large decrease in the electrical power supply. I personally doubt we'll see anything new from Nikon for another 10-12 months, but even if they do the supplies could just be a trickle. My SB-800 came back on Friday from Nikon as "uneconomical to repair". Crap. This morning I bought a used SB-900 for $350 on eBay. My thinking was I didn't want to dither on buying another one in case the supply is very limited and prices will be skyrocketing next week. I use flash a lot. Really, that's the only thing I can think of that I really needed from Nikon for now. About the only break that Nikon seems to have caught here is that Sony might be in a similar mess.

Kent in SD

M635_Guy

   

p.2 #19 · p.2 #19 · "No Prospect of Recovery"

abam wrote:

try doing some good instead of bickering amongst yourselves.

Kindly address someone specifically, or do not throw your disdain around quite so sweepingly, would you please? You have no way of knowing what, if anything, each party to this discussion is doing to help.

Simply suggesting that others help out, and mentioning ways to do so, is a wonderful contribution to the conversation. Snidely implying that no one is doing so... not so much.
